intro: Lappula coronifera, commonly known as the crownflower, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the family Polygonaceae, commonly referred to as the buckwheat family. The plant features basal leaves that are lance-shaped and often covered in fine hairs, while its flowers are small and clustered in dense, greenish-white inflorescences. Lappula coronifera is typically found in moist, calcareous soils along streambanks and in wet meadows. It is a perennial herb that blooms from June to August, producing small, inconspicuous flowers that are pollinated by insects.
